passages.text: This week in Business & Information Services, we published takeaways from our non- deal roadshow with MCO, where we came away more positive on the company's Gen AI strategy, which has evolved to developing agentic solutions for clients in the MA segment, building out MCP servers to interface with external LLMs and leveraging LLMs for edge workflows in MIS not involving a ratings action. Based on our conversations, investor feedback on MCO was positive given its proactive Gen AI strategy that can drive incremental revenue. We also published highlights from our NDR with MH that provided new insights on its digital transformation, strong K- 12 capture rates so far this year and positive growth outlook beyond F2026. Investor sentiment on MH was mixed, with some investors uncertain over the potential impact of Gen AI on the business and others citing upside potential to F2026 revenue and a forthcoming recovery in F2027. This week, we reviewed top takeaways from the 2Q earnings cycle, as well, and noted the intensified debate around whether Gen AI could disrupt certain companies in Business Services, most notably IT. Investor feedback on IT was cautiously optimistic, with a number highlighting early 2026 as when the stock could recover if CV growth reaccelerates. We additionally analyzed the latest consumer credit trends through July and found ongoing improvements in delinquency rates and healthy growth in personal loan originations.
Information Services CLVT, CSGP, EFX, FDS, FICO, IT, MCO, MH, MSCI, SPGI, TRI/TRI.TO, TRU, VRSK
Business Services: ADT, BCO, BFAM, BV, CTAS, HRB, IRM, KFY, KLC, MAN, NATL, RHI, ROL, ULS, VSTS

SPGI, MCO, IT, FICO, FDS, MH, BCO, HRB

Initial jobless claims decreased to \(229k\) for the week ending 8/23 from 234k the week prior, but came slightly above FactSet consensus of \(228k\) . A tightening labor market is incrementally positive for temp staffers MAN and RHI.

US real GDP growth for 2Q was upwardly revised from \(3.0\%\) to \(3.3\%\) , reflecting a rise in business investment into intellectual property such as AI, partially offset by tariffs on imports. Accelerating real GDP growth is incrementally positive for debt issuance volumes and ratings revenue at SPGI and MCO.

The Consumer Confidence Index decreased to 974 in Aug from 98.7 in Jul, reflecting a weaker jobs report and newly announced tariffs, mitigated by more optimism around lower than expected inflation from tariffs, but came above FactSet consensus of 970. A decrease in consumer confidence has negative implications for companies with B2C exposure, including EFX, TRU, FICO and ADT.

TRU disclosed a data breach to the Maine AG office, revealing \(\sim 4.5mm\) individuals were affected by unauthorized access to a third- party application serving its US consumer support operations. The company indicated that some limited personal information was accessed and no credit data was compromised.
CSGP completed its acquisition of Domain Holdings Australia for \(\) 1.9bn\$ Domain is one of Australia's leading property marketplaces focusing primarily on the residential listing space.

MCO announced it intends to secure a majority equity stake in MERIS Ratings, an Egyptian credit rating agency affiliated with MCO, pending regulatory approval. Following the transaction, MERIS will remain an independent affiliate, maintaining
its own methodologies, ratings and management team. Terms of the transaction

GS Business & Information Services Research This WeekAmericas Business & Information Services: Consumer credit trends demonstrated further improvement in July. US consumer credit continued to exhibit improving trends in July despite ongoing macro uncertainty. Non-mortgage delinquencies declined across multiple categories, with \(60+\) day card delinquencies down 15 bps y/y to \(2.76\%\) and personal loan delinquencies down 27 bps to \(3.25\%\) , mitigated by auto loan delinquencies rising 2 bps to \(1.51\%\) in July. Delinquency trends have been broadly declining y/y for cards since January 2025 and personal loans since November 2024, with auto loan delinquencies flat- to- up y/y over the past six months. Meanwhile, new account originations were flat y/y for cards, down modestly for autos after tariff- related pull- forward activity earlier this year and up double- digits for personal loans driven by fintech activity. We favor Buy- rated Fair Isaac for its wide competitive moat and pricing power in the Scores business, which we believe remain intact even after the FHFAs lender choice decision, and for its idiosyncratic platform transformation in the Software business. We stay Neutral- rated on Equifax given state budget, white collar staffing and criminal background screening share shift headwinds in the EWS business, and are sidelined on TransUnion in the context of lending volumes coming below historical averages among the company's fintech and small & regional bank customers. Link to our 8/29 note here.

Americas Business & Information Services: Key takeaways, themes and stock picks in Business & Info Services post 2Q results. The 2Q earnings cycle in Business & Information Services was characterized by an intensified debate over whether Gen AI could negatively disrupt certain companies in the sector. Gartner's 2Q results, which involved a miss- and- cut, ignited investor concerns that Gen AI could replace the company's IT research and insights, sending shares \(28\%\) lower as contract value growth decelerated in the quarter and was guided by management to decelerate further in the second half of the year. Gen AI concerns at Gartner spilled over to other names in the space, including CSGP, FDS, RELGB and WKLNL. Based on takeaways from our recent 2nd annual Silicon Valley AI Field Trip, we believe sustainable moats in Business & Info Services capable of protecting from Gen AI competition include strong user sociology, i.e., having distributed users, power users and embedded workflows that make the product sticky, and proprietary data that cannot be replicated or produced by LLMs. We see Gartner - down \(49\%\) YTD - as oversold given its research and insights are proprietary and cannot be reliably or closely substituted by LLMs. We also believe SPGI is favorably leveraged to Gen AI given assistant and agentic capabilities being incorporated into its products, and its proprietary data. IRM's data center business should additionally benefit from rising Gen AI infrastructure capex to support growing inference needs as enterprise adoption of Gen AI increases. Link to our 8/28 note here.

McGraw Hill (MH, Buy): NDR highlights tailwinds from digital transformation, F2026 execution and medium- term growth outlook. We recently hosted a non- deal roadshow with McGraw Hill's CEO Simon Allen, CFO Bob Sallmann and Head of IR

Danielle Kloeblen, and came away more positive on the company's digital positioning, execution in F2026 and growth potential beyond F2026. MH is continuing to execute its digital transformation, with digital revenue mix rising from \(35\%\) in F2015 to \(65\%\) in F2025 and \(75\%\) over the long- term driven by expanded digital offerings, AI integration, and cross- selling supplemental and intervention solutions. AI is a strategic differentiator for the company, enabling personalized learning for students, better awareness of student performance for teachers and streamlined content creation, with MH's history and reputation serving as a moat against AI- native competitors. Thus far in F2026, K- 12 capture rates are exceeding management's internal expectations and historical levels in the \(25 - 30\%\) range, with a recovery in math and ELA adoptions tracking to lift F2027- F2028 K- 12 core TAM growth. Market shares are also rising in higher ed driven by Evergreen and Inclusive Access. EBITDA margins of \(35\% +\) at MH are sustainable over the long term, supported by digital and AI efficiencies, while visibility remains strong for FCF to rebound in F2027 supported by predictable state adoption cycles. Link to our 8/26 note here.

Moody's (MCO, Neutral): Recent NDR highlights strong positioning with Gen AI. We recently hosted a non- deal roadshow with Moody's Cristina Pieretti (General Manager of Digital Content & Innovation) and Shivani Kak (Head of Investor Relations), and came away more confident in the company's Gen AI strategy and its ability to unlock customer value. MCO has evolved from deploying Gen AI through its Research Assistant to developing agentic solutions that can automate full workflows, such as drafting credit memos and conducting SWOT analysis. Management highlighted a key competitive advantage is its proprietary data, including ratings and research, as well as its curated public data that has been enhanced with tagging and metadata. The company has built MCP servers to interface its data with external LLMs, accessible only to paying clients; MCO does not sell or license data for model training or non- client use. MCO monetizes its Gen AI products by considering client efficiencies gained and labor costs displaced, with strict metering to ensure the pass- through of LLM costs. Gen AI is being deployed primarily in MCO's MA segment, with limited use in MIS for edge tasks such as flagging potential rating triggers and news retrieval, but not for any ratings actions. Management also emphasized the long- term opportunity in private credit, supported by Gen AI infrastructure build- out, while reaffirming its commitment to ratings integrity. Restructuring in MA is driving both reinvestments into Gen AI and margin expansion. Link to our 8/25 note here.

Americas Business & Information Services: Weekly debt issuance, AUM, exchange traded derivative volumes and fund formation as of 8/25/25. Global debt issuance volumes decreased \(8\%\) y/y for the week of 8/18/25, with a \(4\%\) y/y decline YTD and \(4\%\) y/y increase QTD. For the week of 8/18/25, global corporate investment grade issuance declined \(34\%\) y/y, and there was no high yield or leveraged loan issuance, while global financial institutions' issuance increased \(65\%\) and structured finance issuance fell \(18\%\) . Period average S&P index- linked ETF AUM grew \(23\%\) y/y for the week of 8/18/25, with SPGI ESG ETF AUM up \(17\%\) , while MSCI index- linked ETF AUM rose \(24\%\) , with MSCI ESG ETF AUM up \(17\%\) . S&P- linked exchange traded derivative volumes across the CBOE and CME exchanges expanded \(21\%\) y/y for the week of 8/18/25, while MSCI- linked exchange traded derivative volumes across the Eurex, ICE and CBOE

exchanges contracted \(28\%\) . The total number of global funds increased \(7\%\) y/y, with global fund formation down \(35\%\) for the week of 8/18/25, while the total number of ESG funds grew \(4\%\) , with global ESG fund formation down \(89\%\) . Link to our 8/25 note here.

2Q Business Services price action reflected debates over AI impact. In the CY2Q earnings cycle, investors were focused on how Business Services companies could have been disrupted by, or benefited from, growing enterprise adoption of Gen AI. Gartner represented a pivotal moment this past earnings cycle, with the share price declining \(28\%\) in response to miss- and- cut results that investors attributed, at least in part, to Gen AI disintermediation, in contrast with management's explanation that the deceleration in Insights CV growth was due to reduced federal government spending and tariff impacts. Investor concerns over Gen AI also surfaced in quarterly results at HRB (down \(5\%\) ) and RHI (down \(6\%\) ), with spillover effects at CSGP, FDS and several European Business Services names including RELGB and WKLNL. Other Business Services companies that underperformed with 2Q results missed on KPIs (KLC - \(19\%\) , IRM - \(6\%\) , HRB - \(5\%\) , CLVT - \(4\%\) ), had outright revenue declines due to execution factors (BV - \(6\%\) , VSTS - \(6\%\) ), did not meet investor expectations for a guidance raise (ULS - \(12\%\) , TRI - \(10\%\) , VRSK - \(6\%\) ) or exhibited negative cyclical exposures (MSCI - \(9\%\) , EFX - \(8\%\) , RHI - \(6\%\) ). Conversely, companies that outperformed the most exhibited defensive characteristics (BFAM + \(11\%\) , ROL + \(5\%\) , CTAS + \(4\%\) ), beat muted expectations (NATL + \(15\%\) , BCO + \(13\%\) ) or generated upside surprise despite cyclical exposures (CSGP + \(7\%\) , KFY + \(6\%\) , SPGI + \(4\%\) , TRU + \(4\%\) , MAN + \(3\%\) , MCO + \(2\%\) ).
Exhibit 1: Stock price reactions to 2Q results were highly variable 2Q earnings stock price impact

We, Gorge K. Tong, CFA, Sami Nasir, CFA, Anna Wu and Alex Lakritz, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverag, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

The analysts named in this report may have from time to time discussed with our clients, including Goldman Sachs salespersons and traders, or may discuss in this report, trading strategies that reference catalysts or events that may have a near- term impact on the market price of the equity securities discussed in this report, which impact may be directionally counter to the analyst's published price target expectations for such stocks. Any such trading strategies are distinct from and do not affect the analyst's fundamental equity rating for such stocks, which rating reflects a stock's return potential relative to its coverage universe as described herein.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them

may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
